algorithmExplanation: An algorithm is a set of rules that takes in one or more inputs, then performs inner calculations and data manipulations and returns an output or a set of outputs. In short, algorithms make life easy. From complex data manipulations and hashes, to simple arithmetic, algorithms follow a set of steps to produce a useful result. One example of an algorithm would be a simple function that takes two input values, adds them together, and returns their sum.
aboutUs: We are a group of programmers helping each other build new things, whether it be writing complex encryption programs, or simple ciphers. Our goal is to work together to document and model beautiful, helpful and interesting algorithms using code. We are an open-source community - anyone can contribute. We check each other's work, communicate and collaborate to solve problems. We strive to be welcoming, respectful, yet make sure that our code follows the latest programming guidelines.
programmingLanguages: We support many programming languages. Each language has its own GitHub repository where all the code for the algorithms is stored. Here is a list of the current programming languages:
contribute: We encourage you to contribute to these repositories. If you have an algorithm that you want to add, a change you want to make, or a bug you want to fix, please do so. But before you do, make sure you have read the contributing guidelines found in CONTRIBUTING.md in the repository. Make sure that you are respectful, helpful, and using the latest version of the language. After reading the contribution guidelines, please fork the repository, work on your changes and then submit them as a pull request. You can also help us translate the website using [Weblate]. If you have any other languages you want to add, or any strings you want to fix, you're welcome to contribute.
welcomeTitle: Welcome to GitHub's largest open-source algorithm library
donateText: Another way you can support us is to make a donation via [Liberapay]. Even a small donation is much appreciated. By donating, it means that you appreciate and like our work. If you don't like our work, there's no need to donate. If you donate, top members will be able to contribute further to The Algorithms projects. We appreciate donations from everyone, from everywhere, no matter the amount.
addExplanation: Add an explanation for this algorithm
addExplanationInfo: This algorithm does not yet have a explanation. The explanations are located in the [Algorithms-Explanations] repository. If you want to add an explanation, fork this repository and add the explanation as a markdown file ([example]). Once you are finished, you can open a pull request to merge your explanation.
editPageHelp: If you have any issues, feel free to go on our [Discord] server, and ask for help.
addImplementationInfo: To add a implementation in another language, please visit the repository for that language and follow the instructions given in the README.md and CONTRIBUTING.md.
addImplementationMissing: Here are the links to repositories still missing implementations:
addTranslationInfo: The explanation to this algorithm wasn't yet translated to your language. To translate this explanation, please visit the [Algorithms-Explanation] repository. Fork this repository and add your translation as a new Markdown file based on the English [{ogFilename}] in the correct folder for your locale ({locale}). When you have translated the file, you can create a new pull request to merge your translation.
indexMetaDescription: Open Source resource for learning Data Structures & Algorithms and their implementation in any Programming Language
